13 
 
 
4) Annex II 
 
Additional information on climate change mitigation and adaptation in Iceland 
Iceland’s anthropogenic emissions of greenhouse gases amounted to almost 4.9 million 
tons in 2018, without LULUCF. The main sources of emissions are: Industrial processes 
(42%), burning of fossil fuels, mostly in road transport and fisheries (37%), agriculture (13%) 
and waste management (6%). Stationary energy – electricity production and heating – is 
produced almost 100% from renewable resources, hydro and geothermal. Some emissions 
of CO2 in geothermal steam are attributed to geothermal energy production (3% of total 
emissions), while such emissions are much smaller than from energy production from fossil 
fuels. 
 
LULUCF 
The general impacts of land use activities are well understood, and LULUCF is a priority in 
Iceland´s Climate Action Plan. The government supports sustainable land use practices, and 
nature-based solutions such as restoration of woodlands, wetlands and other native 
ecosystems in addition to afforestation and revegetation practices. Also, the government 
discourages further wetlands draining and unsustainable land use practices. Iceland 
provides only partial information in LULUCF accounting to the Convention, as sufficient 
knowledge on carbon budgets for all land types is not available. Efforts are under way to 
improve LULUCF accounting and strengthen its scientific underpinnings, to ensure that 
Iceland fulfils the requirements of the EU LULUCF Regulation No 2018/841. 
There are significant reported and estimated emissions in the LULUCF sector, mostly legacy 
emissions from wetlands drained in the 20th Century. These emissions can be reduced or 
halted by reclamation of drained wetlands. Iceland also has great potential for carbon 
uptake by reforestation, revegetation and afforestation; actions that actively reverse 
historical soil erosion and loss of woodlands. As for LULUCF activities, Iceland has 
developed good accounting for afforestation and other activities related to forests, as well 
as revegetation, but less robust accounting for wetlands draining and reclamation and 
other activities.  
 
Mitigation 
Iceland’s main instrument for climate mitigation is the Climate Action Plan. The present 
plan was presented in 2018, and thoroughly revised in 2020. The plan outlines 48 actions 
across all relevant sectors intended to help Iceland meet its Paris Agreement targets for 
2030 and reach the government’s aim to make Iceland carbon neutral before 2040. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
14 
 
Adaptation 
Iceland has prioritized mitigation, in order to limit net greenhouse gas emissions to reach 
the Paris Agreement’s target of holding the increase in the global average temperature well 
below 2 degrees C above pre-industrial levels, and to pursue efforts to limit the 
temperature increase to 1.5 degrees C. However, adaptation measures will also be needed, 
in order to tackle the unavoidable impacts that will accompany higher temperatures and 
associated changes. Impacts of climate change on Iceland include receding glaciers, 
expanding woodlands, changes in sea level (higher levels in some parts, but lower in other), 
warming seas with changes in species distributions, and increased risks of many types of 
natural disasters. Of particular concern is ocean acidification and its possible impact on 
marine life and fisheries. Work is currently under way for a national adaptation strategy 
due to be finalized in 2021. 
 
Carbon Neutrality in 2040 
The goal of carbon neutrality is to be reached by cutting emissions in all sectors, and by 
increasing carbon removals from the atmosphere, including by restoration, revegetation, 
afforestation, and carbon capture and mineralization in rock formations (Carbfix). Efforts 
are currently under way in all these categories, which need to be strengthened for Iceland 
to reach carbon neutrality in 2040 and a state of negative net emissions after that. Robust 
carbon accounting methods are also available for these activities, which will help Iceland 
keeping track of progress towards the goal. Carbon accounting and reporting in the LULUCF 
sector in general needs to be improved, as is discussed above.  
A new project outlining pathways towards carbon neutrality is currently being launched 
and will include consultations with stakeholders and the public. It can be guided by 
currently available accounting methods for carbon removals, but it is foreseen that the 
accounting framework for the carbon neutrality goal will be revised in a few years' time, 
when a more robust LULUCF accounting framework will be in place in Iceland.   
Iceland is currently working on its long-term low greenhouse gas emission development 
strategy, in accordance with Art. 4, Para.19, of the Paris Agreement. The project on pathways 
towards carbon neutrality is seen as providing needed information for the strategy, which 
is planned to be submitted this year.

India’s Updated First Nationally 
Determined Contribution Under 
Paris Agreement 
(2021-2030) 
 
 
 
 
 
August 2022 Submission to UNFCCC 
 
 
Government of India 
P a g e | 1 of 3  
 
INDIA’S UPDATED FIRST NATIONALLY DETERMINED CONTRIBUTION 
WORKING TOWARDS CLIMATE JUSTICE 
 
Pursuant to decision 1/CP.20, India submitted its Intended Nationally Determined 
Contribution (NDC) to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate 
Change (UNFCCC) on 2nd October, 2015. In accordance with decision 1/CP.21, 
paragraph 22, India’s Intended NDC is now its first NDC under the Paris 
Agreement. 
 
The Article 4, paragraph 9 of the Paris Agreement provides that each Party shall 
communicate a nationally determined contribution every five years in accordance 
with decision 1/CP.21. Decision 1/CP.21, paragraphs 23 and 24, requests Parties 
to communicate or update this contribution and to do so every five years, pursuant 
to Article 4, paragraph 9, of the Agreement.  
 
Therefore, in accordance with the aforesaid provision of the Paris Agreement read 
with relevant decisions, India hereby communicates an update to its first NDC 
submitted earlier on October 2, 2015, for the period up to 2030, as under:   
 
 
1. To put forward and further propagate a healthy and sustainable way of 
living based on traditions and values of conservation and 
moderation, including through a mass movement for ‘LIFE’– ‘Lifestyle 
for Environment’ as a key to combating climate change [ UPDATED]. 
 
2. To adopt a climate friendly and a cleaner path than the one followed 
hitherto by others at corresponding level of economic development. 
P a g e | 2 of 3  
 
3. To reduce Emissions Intensity of its GDP by 45 percent by 2030, from 
2005 level [UPDATED].   
 
4. To achieve about 50 percent cumulative electric power installed 
capacity from non-fossil fuel-based energy resources by 2030, with 
the help of transfer of technology and low-cost international finance 
including from Green Climate Fund (GCF) [UPDATED].  
 
5. To create an additional carbon sink of 2.5 to 3 billion tonnes of CO2 
equivalent through additional forest and tree cover by 2030. 
 
6. To better adapt to climate change by enhancing investments in 
development programmes in sectors vulnerable to climate change, 
particularly agriculture, water resources, Himalayan region, coastal 
regions, health and disaster management. 
 
7. To mobilize domestic and new & additional funds from developed 
countries to implement the above mitigation and adaptation actions in 
view of the resource required and the resource gap. 
 
8. To build capacities, create domestic framework and international 
architecture for quick diffusion of cutting edge climate technology in India 
and for joint collaborative R&D for such future technologies. 
 
India’s NDC is ambitious, and it is a significant contribution towards achieving the 
goals of the Paris Agreement. Environmentally sustainable, low carbon initiatives 
are underpinning all key sectors of the Indian economy.  
 
P a g e | 3 of 3  
 
India reaffirms its commitment to the UNFCCC and the Paris Agreement on 
Climate Change. 
 
This update to India’s existing NDC is a step forward towards our long term goal 
of reaching net-zero by 2070.   
 
No change in the other sections or text or otherwise of the document containing 
existing first NDC is proposed at this stage. India reserves the right to provide 
further updates by way of additional submissions on its NDC, as and when 
required.

Title: Iraq First NDC

  Executive Summary 
   This document is a voluntary national contribution and a vision that represents 
Iraq's highest policy in dealing with the issue of climate change nationally and 
internationally. This document comes in response to the Paris Agreement adopted at 
the 21st Conference of the Parties to the Framework Convention on Climate Change 
(UNFCCC). 
   As a developing country, Iraq believes that solutions to climate change can only be 
achieved with the active participation of all countries and within the principles of the United 
Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change and the Paris Agreement, based on 
common but differentiated responsibility according to national circumstances and capabilities 
and historical responsibility for the occurrence of this issue. 
   Since its early accession to the UNFCCC, Iraq started working on implementing many 
projects and studies aimed at adapting to the effects of climate change and mitigating 
emissions, but most of these projects have been completely halted as a result of the fierce 
confrontation with ISIS terrorist gangs, which caused catastrophic consequences that affected 
all sectors of life, threatened security and social peace, completely destroyed infrastructure 
and displaced hundreds of thousands of people, in addition to the damage to the economic 
sector already affected by the fluctuation and decline in oil prices and the terrorist 
organisation's control over several oil wells and oil and industrial installations and forced the 
   The impact of climate change on Iraq has been evident in the significant decrease in its 
water resources and the increasing rise in temperature rates in excess of global averages. 
However, Iraq presents this ambitious plan in which all national plans and strategies related 
to climate change have been adopted to be compatible with the national development needs 
and orientations of all sectors to ensure the achievement of the desired goals nationally and 
internationally in making gradual qualitative and radical transformations according to the 
available national capabilities if security and peace are achieved and economic resources are 
provided to ensure a decent life for the Iraqi people 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
3 
 
 
 
 
 
 
    
Chapter One 
 
National circumstances and possibilities: 
 
   Iraq is located in southwest Asia within the arid and semi-arid regions, and has acquired 
from this location its semi-continental climate influenced by the Mediterranean climate, 
where Iraq's climate is characterised by a wide daily and annual thermal range, due to the 
lack of large bodies of water that reduce the cold of winter and the heat of summer, and the 
lack of rainfall in the direction from the northeast to the southwest, and due to this 
geographical location it is considered one of the most vulnerable countries to the effects of 
global warming and climate change in its multiple dimensions. 
   Iraq's population is estimated at more than 40 million, with an annual growth rate of 
2.However, Iraq's economy and business as usual has not been at the required level that meets 
the needs of the Iraqi citizen, as it has been clearly fluctuating and has fallen for a long time 
to low levels due to the exceptional circumstances of wars, conflicts and economic blockade 
during and after the previous regime and the huge numbers of displaced and displaced people 
due to its exposure to ISIS terrorist attacks, and it is difficult for the annual Iraqi national 
budget to provide the necessary funds for reconstruction and the return of displaced and 
displaced people to their homes, as the terrorist organisation ISIS and the war it launched on 
Iraq caused serious damage to the infrastructure and infrastructure of the country. However, 
despite this, Iraq supports the global trend and the paths set by the Paris Agreement, which 
aims to preserve the planet and calls on developed and major industrialised countries to 
commit to mitigation promises and provide financial and technical support, technology 
transfer and transparent implementation towards developing countries to help them 
implement their national contributions and achieve sustainable development goals within 
their territories and enable them to survive by establishing a diversified and flexible economy 
that is responsive to current and future climate changes, so Iraq's desire is strong towards 
rebuilding destroyed cities according to modern building systems to become green, 
sustainable cities, which has had a direct impact on the country's ability to rebuild its cities. 
This has directly affected the country's ability to enable many national sectors to recover and 
face the risks of climate change, especially since most of the available resources have been 
diverted towards the health sector to prevent it from collapsing as a result of the Corona 
pandemic and the major health issues that have placed a great burden on this important 
sector, and the economic situation is still unclear and unpredictable 
   Iraq has natural ecosystems rich in biodiversity, but its geographical location within arid 
and semi-arid regions has made it one of the countries most vulnerable to the impact of global 
climate change, as evidenced by unprecedented climatic phenomena such as low rainfall 
rates, low water levels in lakes and rivers, unprecedented temperature rises of more than 
double the global average, fires, increased dust storms in their intensity, frequency and time 
periods, and increased desertification, which caused pressure on ecosystems and the balances 
4 
 
that they create, which contributed to the reduction in the spread of many endemic plant 
species and the decrease in the number of wild animals or their extinction as a result of 
climate change. According to the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN), 
this is considered a direct threat in terms of severity to ecosystems and biodiversity, but 
despite these pressures, large areas of Iraq are still of global and local importance, for 
example the marsh areas, which have been included on the World Heritage List because of 
their importance, in addition to the declaration of many protected areas with their natural 
richness and the environmental services they provide with an important economic return. 
 
   Surface water is the main water resource in Iraq, consisting of the waters of the Tigris and 
Euphrates rivers and their tributaries and the Shatt al-Arab. There has been a significant 
decrease in Iraq's water resources due to the many dams and irrigation and development 
projects established on these rivers in neighbouring countries to secure their water shares and 
use them to generate hydroelectric power, which has affected Iraq's water share and quality, 
and the effects of climate change have caused a decrease in the amount of water coming into 
its rivers, as the water sector is one of the most vulnerable sectors in the face of climate 
change. 
Although our country's coastline on the Arabian Gulf is very narrow, the rising sea level 
could threaten the southern region with drowning, especially Basra Governorate, which 
overlooks the Gulf and where Iraq's economic capacity is concentrated. In addition, the rising 
temperature and acidity of these waters affects the biodiversity of the marine environment 
and coral reefs in Iraq's territorial waters and also affects the tourism aspect in this area, so 
this issue is of exceptional importance in dealing with this issue. 
   The agricultural sector is one of the most water-consuming sectors in Iraq (about 35 billion 
cubic metres/year), where the percentage of water consumption in this sector accounts for 
85%. Due to the use of open and old irrigation channels, fragile or weak water resources 
management, dilapidated infrastructure, the use of old irrigation techniques (surface 
irrigation) for some crops such as rice and traditional farming patterns, the amounts of 
irrigation water exceeded the specified water quotas, which led over time to high water levels 
and soil salinisation. 
   The transport sector is an important sector in the economy of any country, and all economic 
and life activities such as shopping, housing and entertainment cannot perform their role and 
function without linking to transport lines due to the impact of other economic sectors such as 
industry, trade and tourism, and this sector suffers from poor infrastructure, which is the main 
pillar of transport development due to the lack of laws, legislation and projects that support 
the trend towards sustainable, collective and environmentally friendly means of transport.  
   Iraq suffers from a severe weakness in the infrastructure supporting the industrial sector due 
to the lack of cities and industrial zones that provide the necessary infrastructure for the 
establishment of various industries, in addition to the weakness of the support structure for 
industry and investment, which contributed to the deterioration of this sector. The weakness 
of the comprehensive knowledge infrastructure of communications and information 
technology networks, as well as the infrastructure of standards, metrics and quality, and the 
weak efforts to support the private sector to become a key partner in economic development 
5 
 
through clear and sophisticated programmes, all of which have clearly and tangibly affected 
the reality of the industrial sector and its inability to keep pace with the global march of 
progress. 
 
Environmental laws and legislation: 
The Iraqi state, especially after 2003, issued many legislations aimed at protecting the 
environment, but the country's security conditions did not help in fully implementing them, 
and there is a need for other legislations and modernising the existing ones to be in line with 
the requirements of confronting climate change. 
Environmental awareness: 
   Environmental awareness is the generalisation and deepening of environmental knowledge 
among all segments and groups of society through appropriate environmental means and 
messages, and motivating them to contribute and participate individually and collectively in 
protecting the environment and preserving its resources. Since climate change is the issue of 
the age and women and children are more vulnerable than men to climate change, it is 
necessary to raise full environmental awareness about climate change and develop strategies, 
plans, laws and legislation to raise environmental awareness among all segments of society, 
especially vulnerable groups. 
 
 
 
Research and development: 
 Addressing climate change requires strengthening scientific research and technological 
development in several areas, including technology transfer, economic aspects and related 
aspects of industry, oil, energy, transport development and other areas related to climate 
change and citizen life in order to mitigate the effects of climate change and adapt to it, so it 
is necessary to give importance to this aspect and provide the opportunity to prepare broad 
and deep studies on climate change and its multifaceted effects and support graduate students 
(master and doctoral) in adopting research and studies on climate change topics and increase 
the knowledge aspect of climate change. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
6 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Chapter Two 
 
 Climate change impacts, vulnerability and adaptation actions 
 
   The effects of climate change on various Iraqi sectors have become known to all and have 
cast a shadow on all life in Iraq, especially in light of the fragile conditions of the country and 
the dilapidated infrastructure, and the results of these effects have been clear on the sectors 
that directly affect the life of the citizen and his economic, water and food security, and their 
effects have been evident on the economic, health and life aspects in general, as projections 
based on national numerical climate models indicate a steady increase in temperature ranging 
between (0.9 m° ) since 2007 and may reach (3. 5 m) by the year 2100, according to the 
projections,5 m° ) by 2100 according to the aforementioned projections, which increases the 
critical situation in a country where the temperature has risen above (50 m° ) on a number of 
summer days of the year, not to mention the clear decrease in the annual rainfall rates, which 
is expected to witness a significant and continuous decrease that may reach in 2100 a 
decrease of more than 30% compared to its rates during the period 1938 - 1978, according to 
the forecasts of the General Authority for Climate Change. This is a clear indication of the 
reasons for the clear increase in the occurrence of extreme situations such as heat waves, 
drought and sudden heavy rainfall. For example, there are large waves of drought that led to 
an increase in the area of desertification, which affected the increase in dust and dust storms 
7 
 
during the year, whose intensity, frequency, frequency and time periods led to a noticeable 
increase in the number of asthma cases in Iraqi society, especially among children and the 
elderly, and the spread of diseases and cancers significantly. In addition, climate change has 
exacerbated the issue of water scarcity in the Tigris and Euphrates rivers and their tributaries, 
as the World Bank estimates for 2011 indicated that there is a significant shortage of 
renewable water resources for Iraq compared to the actual need during the period from 2000 
to 2009, while this percentage is expected to reach 37% during the period from 2020 to 2030, 
which will increase to 51% during the period from 2040 to 2050, which explains the reason 
for the major collapse in the agricultural sector, which has left its clear effects on agricultural 
production Iraq's economy, natural systems and biodiversity, the loss of vegetation cover, the 
threat to the marine coastal areas overlooking the Arabian Gulf, especially in Basra 
Governorate in southern Iraq, due to sea level rise and water warming, the impact on coral 
reefs and biodiversity in the marine environment and the loss of areas of coastal land, in 
addition to its effects on the energy sector, as Basra Governorate is the main centre of oil 
wealth in Iraq, which has created pressure on the national economy and a threat to the 
stability of the country, making it very difficult to achieve sustainable development in all its 
vital sectors, which hinders6). 
   Iraq is working on preparing a National Adaptation Plan (NAP) with funding from the 
Green Climate Fund (GCF) in cooperation with the United Nations Environment Programme 
(UNEP), which will be among the basic plans that the country will rely on in implementing 
this policy to ensure resilience for all vulnerable national priority sectors over the next three 
years to minimise potential risks and find effective ways to sustain water resources and 
address acute water scarcity and deteriorating water quality. As a result of the difficult 
economic conditions that Iraq is going through, especially after the COVID-19 pandemic and 
the unprecedented drop in oil prices, its implementation of this policy will need regional 
cooperation and international support to enable it to establish strong and resilient health 
systems to protect human health, protect natural systems and biodiversity, enhance resilience 
to impacts and disaster risks associated with local climate change scenarios, and promote 
adaptation in vulnerable sectors. 
   Given the synergistic relationship between the sectors, the preparation and implementation 
of an action plan for adaptation measures and the realisation of the required benefits for each 
of the main sectors affected by climate change and within the framework of the relevant 
national and sectoral strategies such as the National Water Strategy, the National Strategy for 
Agriculture, the National Biodiversity Strategy and the National Framework for Integrated 
Drought Risk Management in Iraq will lead to strengthening the national capacity to address 
the impacts of climate change on different sectors, especially those sectors that are most 
sensitive and vulnerable, as follows: 
 
 
1. Water Resources Sector: 
 
Top Pivots:    
1. Sustainable investment and preservation of groundwater for future generations, water harvesting, 
minimising water losses, using modern technologies to monitor and control groundwater 
reservoirs and determine their quality, and the need to maintain the pH balance of 
groundwater in general. 
8 
 
2. Desalination of seawater (and river water when required) and the use of renewable 
energy to power desalination plants and the development of new technologies. 
3. The construction of numerous dams and reservoirs to collect water, prevent flood risks, 
provide water quotas during dry periods, and recharge and sustain underground aquifers.  
4. Raising the efficiency of irrigation water use and working on finding modern high-
efficiency irrigation methods, minimising water consumption in accordance with the 
quality of crops, the nature of the soil and climatic conditions in order to adapt to the 
sharp decline in water resources, rehabilitating major irrigation projects, gradually 
linking spouts to the main drainage areas or evaporation basins to avoid their return to 
rivers, and using non-traditional water sources to provide the necessary water quotas for 
agricultural, industrial and service uses such as oil well injection and green belt irrigation, 
and reducing water wastage quantitatively and qualitatively. 
5. Activating national policies, laws and legislations that urge citizens to rationalise water 
use, with the need for specific measures against those who deliberately waste water. 
6. Urge the countries bordering the Tigris and Euphrates rivers and their tributaries (Turkey 
and Iran) to respect Iraq's rights to its shared waters and strengthen regional cooperation 
with them to achieve water and climate security, which requires regional risk assessment, 
joint crisis management, damage-sharing and consideration of the country's water 
demands from shared rivers to meet its water needs for development sectors to achieve 
security and peace. 
Overarching goal: Increase the resilience of the country's water resources sector by 
adopting an integrated approach to address the increasing future need for water demand 
and reduce the potential deficit by developing water uses in line with the challenges of 
climate change and applying the themes mentioned in the Water and Land Resources 
Strategy until 2035 by providing financial and technical support and introducing 
alternative and non-conventional sources, taking into account the improvement of 
infrastructure and efficiency of supply and preserving water sources from pollution as 
part of the sustainability of these sources. 
 
2. Agriculture: 
Top Pivots: 
1. Reducing and rehabilitating soil, rangeland and vegetation degradation, improving land management 
practices and adopting smart and conservation agriculture, especially in the field of agriculture and  
2. Modernising, improving and developing agricultural practices and livestock development 
to achieve climate change adaptation.  
3. Establishing greenhouse and greenhouse farms and laboratories for tissue culture 
breeding of varieties resistant to climate change. 
Overarching goal: Increase the resilience of the agricultural sector to climate change to 
protect and enhance the country's food security, reduce soil degradation, increase agricultural 
revenues to achieve economic diversification, reduce poverty and support rural women 
through the use of modern techniques and technologies as part of achieving the Sustainable 
Development Goals (SDGs). 
 
 
 
 
9 
 
 
 
 
 
 
3. The health sector: 
Key points: 
1.  Strengthening the resilience of the health sector by preventing diseases caused by 
climate change.  
2. Rehabilitate and restore the resilience of health-vulnerable communities and poor 
communities exposed to health risks and adapt to the adverse effects of climate change.  
3. Raise health awareness among communities vulnerable to climate change-related 
diseases and support the health and family programme. 
4. Combating endemic and epidemic diseases caused by climate change.  
Overarching goal: Increase the resilience of the health sector to climate change by providing 
the necessary and comprehensive support to health institutions and infrastructure to 
strengthen national response, rehabilitate vulnerable communities and build their resilience 
and adaptive capacity, which will contribute to the achievement of the Sustainable 
Development Goals (SDGs). 
 
4.  Natural systems and forests: 
 
Top Pivots: 
1. Increase the number of natural reserves and consider the diversity of these reserves to 
ensure the protection of as many endangered species and fragile ecosystems as possible, 
while enforcing laws and legislation that ensure the realisation of this protection. 
Rehabilitate forests, increase their area and manage them sustainably to contribute to 
enhancing their role in environmental protection and carbon sequestration, while 
enforcing laws and legislation that ensure this protection. 
2. Maintain ecosystems that provide environmental services and utilise some of them to 
prevent environmental risks and disasters. 
3. Genetic improvement of productive plant species to create high-yielding varieties that 
can withstand harsh conditions. 
4. Creating oases in desert and arid ecosystems to protect biodiversity from climate change. 
5. Filling the gaps in the laws and regulations in force to protect this vital sector. 
The overarching goal: Protect and maintain ecosystems by increasing their resilience to 
climate change impacts and adopting nature-based climate solutions to protect fragile, rare 
and most vulnerable environments. 
 
5. Coastal areas and sea level rise: 
 
  Top Pivots: 
1- Repair the environmental damage caused to the coastal areas in southern Iraq, address the 
expansion of the salt tongue from the sea towards the Shatt al-Arab and Basra city, and 
restore the marine environment to its former state. 
10 
 
2- Protect coasts, minimise erosion and preserve ecosystems by encouraging the planting of 
plants and trees that minimise erosion. 
3- Protecting coastal natural resources and preparing coral reef rehabilitation programmes. 
4- Using modern information systems, modelling and climate scenarios to assess the future 
impacts of sea level rise and temperature increase, enhance the capacity for strategic 
planning and proactive adaptation to this phenomenon, and protect the coastal strip south 
of Basra. 
Overarching goal: Develop strategies to protect the marine environment, its biodiversity and 
coastal areas to minimise erosion, increase resilience to sea level rise, increase carbon 
sequestration, preserve related natural environments and address risks and threats to marine 
life and infrastructure. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
6. Sanitation and waste sector: 
 
Top Pivots:  
1. Treatment and recycling of wastewater and wastewater for use in the agricultural sector 
for restricted and unrestricted irrigation through tertiary treatment, as well as for use in 
the industrial and energy sectors. 
2. Providing model wastewater treatment plants in villages and rural communities to 
produce water suitable for irrigation and mobile plants for on-site treatment of organic 
waste to produce biogas and organic fertiliser. 
3. Supporting and assigning industrial wastewater treatment plants to large and medium-
sized industrial facilities to provide alternative and non-traditional water sources and 
minimise river water pollution. 
4. Rehabilitate the sanitation sector to increase the resilience of the water sector and 
minimise the negative impacts of climate change. 
5. Encourage investment and provide all the necessary requirements, while involving the 
private sector in the process of proper solid waste management, recycling and treatment 
by technical methods and using modern technology to benefit from it in the production of 
electrical energy and kerosene fuel to preserve natural resources. 
Overarching goal: Support integrated waste management and promote and improve waste 
management and recycling to produce energy from solid waste, preserve the environment, 
improve the quality of treated water, and reduce energy consumption as part of achieving the 
Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). 
 
7.  Climate and recurring and slow-onset events and risks resulting from climate change: 
 
Top Pivots: 
1. Building and developing a monitoring and early warning system and capacity building to 
monitor extreme and extreme weather events such as droughts, floods, rain, dust and dust 
storms to take the necessary preparations and minimise human and economic losses. 
11 
 
2. Preparation of an atlas of deaths and economic losses caused by extreme events due to 
climate change in Iraq Establishing a nationwide network of weather stations to monitor 
and provide meteorological and hydrological information. 
3. Providing financial and technical support to equip computer technology, remote sensing, 
analysis and prediction of climate variability according to IPCC scenarios as part of 
proactive adaptation to minimise the maximum loss and damage that may result and to 
create future climate models and scenarios for Iraq for the end of the 21st century. 
4. Strengthening national and regional partnerships to manage crises and climate change 
disasters and reduce associated risks. 
5. Enhancing the resilience of ecosystems to extreme events (floods, torrents and droughts) 
to reduce the risk of natural disasters related to climate change. 
The overarching goal: The country aims to increase the capacity of theُ infrastructure to 
predict and improve preparedness by reducing exposure to climate risks and increasing the 
resilience and adaptive capacity of sectors affected by the adverse effects of climate change. 
 
8. Higher Education, Scientific Research, Science and Technology 
 
Top Pivots: 
1. Establishing scientific departments specialised in climate change in universities, 
colleges and relevant institutes. 
2. Working to align academic projects and theses of postgraduate students with the 
national needs in the subject of climate change in accordance with the approved 
international standards. 
The overarching goal: Adopt scientific research and technological development as a key 
pillar of success through joint work between national sectors to achieve the objectives of 
this document. 
 
 
 
9. Energy sector 
 
 Top Pivots: 
1-   Using a nature base solution to afforest the land around power plants. 
2-   Improving transport and distribution efficiency and adopting modern technological 
methods that help adapt to high temperatures. 
3-   Changing the specifications of electrical equipment used in the electricity sector in 
line with increasing temperatures. 
4-   Achieving balance and integration between different means of transport and 
making them an integrated system to maximise the volume of transport in Iraq 
and setting regulations governing this. 
• Develop and provide mass public transport and infrastructure to avoid traffic 
congestion and improve lifestyles, including the provision of railway lines to 
transport passengers, goods and equipment between governorates and improve 
their efficiency. 
12 
 
• Provide advanced transport technologies that are flexible and resilient to the 
adverse effects of climate change. 
• Seek to develop airports and land, sea and river transport centres and install 
modern, environmentally friendly trains such as electric-powered trains. 
• Supporting maritime transport and its importance in linking Iraq to the world 
and its impact on international trade and raising the standard of living of the 
individual. 
• Conduct comprehensive studies to assess the impacts of climate change and 
rising temperatures on the transport sector. 
 
Overarching goal: Increase the resilience of the energy sector to climate change by 
supporting adaptation programmes and working simultaneously with mitigation to strengthen 
the national response to climate change and increase the percentage of the population 
benefiting from electricity and transport services. 
 
10. 
Tourism and World Heritage (natural and cultural) 
 
       Tourism (spatial, archaeological, religious, environmental), archaeological and heritage 
museums, various galleries, buildings, markets, khans, heritage houses, festivals, 
conferences, cinema, theatre, drama, plastic arts, fashion, publications, exhibitions, 
advertising, craft industries, literary heritage such as poetry, prose, tales, novels, stories, 
proverbs, music, institutions that deal with childhood and culture, and community awareness 
are an important source of national income and a companion to fossil fuels if they are 
activated, as well as important archaeological sites, such as historical capitals, and the need 
for their maintenance, promotion, and excavation of important new sites, as we have a list of 
important sites Community awareness is an important source of national income and a 
companion to fossil fuels if it is activated, as well as important archaeological sites such as 
historical capitals and the need to maintain and promote them and excavate important new 
sites, as we have a list of tens of thousands of archaeological sites that are waiting for their 
turn to be excavated and many of them are directly affected by climate change or because 
they are located near the main riverbeds and current and future dam sites. 
Top Pivots: 
1. Promote the traditional knowledge of local people to minimise poverty and improve 
socio-economic conditions. 
2. Work to preserve heritage by registering archaeological, heritage and cultural sites in Iraq 
as World Heritage Sites to protect them from the negative effects of climate change and 
the international community's contribution to their protection.  
3. Conserve natural ecosystems from the negative impacts of climate change, protect 
ecosystem services for local people, and sustain the exceptional universal values of the 
World Heritage property. 
4. Strengthening the management plan for the Southern Iraq Marshes World Heritage 
property by adding a paragraph assessing the adverse impacts of climate change on the 
exceptional universal value of this World Heritage property. 
 
Overarching goal: Increase the resilience of the tourism and world heritage sector and 
promote it as one of the most important sources of economic diversification in the 
13 
 
country, protect archaeological sites, world heritage and indigenous peoples from the 
threats of climate change and promote sustainable ecotourism. 
Chapter Three  
Mitigation measures and co-benefits: 
   The main objective of mitigation policies is to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by taking 
measures and plans to prepare a document that strikes a balance between the requirements of 
the UNFCCC and its Paris Agreement on the one hand and the diversification of the 
economy, the sustainability of fossil fuel exports and the stability of the global market for this 
type of fuel on the other hand to ensure the achievement of sustainable development goals 
until suitable alternatives are found and to limit the impact of response measures taken by 
developed countries on the economies of developing countries and the negative social and 
environmental implications and consequences that will cast a shadow on the economy. 
   The amount of reduction will be determined according to the nationally appropriate 
mitigation measures that Iraq will submit to the UNFCCC secretariat in the future in the form 
of plans, strategies, programmes and projects, which will be based on the baseline amount of 
the business-as-usual amount for each project that includes emission reductions and 
according to the main emitting sectors, targeting the main gases in the IPCC greenhouse gas 
lists, namely carbon dioxide, methane and nitrous oxide. 
  The most important sectors through which Iraq will work to achieve its NDC goals and 
diversify the sources of its national economy are oil, gas, electricity, industry, trade, 
agriculture, transport, waste and the housing sector. 
Pathways to mitigate emissions of CO2 and other greenhouse gases can be characterised as 
follows: 
- 
Widespread dissemination of the culture of environmentally friendly technologies 
that reduce emissions across all target gases, with a focus on mechanisms related to 
improving energy efficiency. 
- 
Mobilise efforts for mitigation measures to include all emitters. 
- 
Dissemination of knowledge and capacity building with support from developed to 
developing countries to ensure consistency among States Parties to ensure balance 
and equality of opportunity while taking into account the national circumstances 
and needs of each country. 
   Since its early accession to the Convention and its signing of the Paris Agreement, Iraq has 
been working on projects and strategic studies to introduce clean and renewable energies, 
improve energy efficiency, sound environmental carbon management and increase the area of 
green spaces. Projects have been initiated to introduce liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) as a 
fuel for vehicles in addition to the traditional fuels used and other pioneering projects in these 
fields and for many national sectors, including work on converting the lighting of many main 
streets in Baghdad to solar energy and developing future plans to convert some power plants 
to solar power, as well as the conversion of some power plants to solar energy. 
- 
Raising awareness of the importance of rationalising energy consumption. 
- 
Spreading the culture of using energy-efficient LED lighting to all government and 
commercial buildings. 
- 
Issuing energy efficiency labels by the Central Agency for Standardisation and 
Quality Control to ensure the use of environmentally friendly goods and services. 
14 
 
- 
Tyre recycling by the Ministry of Industry to reduce emissions. 
- 
Issuing green building codes, which is a policy in the creation of smart green 
buildings. 
- 
Issuance of the Solar Energy Law. 
- 
Utilisation of associated gas in the Basrah Gas Company. 
   ًً In addition to projects that have been implemented in the Kurdistan Region of Iraq, such as 
the establishment of power plants that run on liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) fuel instead of 
heavy fuel, the establishment of brick factories that use LPG instead of black oil, and iron 
production factories that run on kerosene instead of black oil, there are also many projects 
under completion, such as the project to exploit associated gas for power generation, cement 
factories that operate using waste-to-energy technology, a project to exploit associated gas for 
electricity production, and a project to treat wastewater and reuse it for irrigation of green 
belts, which is implemented in cooperation with the Japanese JICA organisation in Erbil 
governorate. This is not to mention the afforestation operations, increasing the areas of 
forests and planting green belts, noting that most of the new cities being built in the Kurdistan 
Region are sustainable cities that rely on smart lighting and the reuse of wastewater for 
irrigation to increase green areas and many others. 
International support and technology transfer is exceptionally important in preventing the 
waste of associated gas, which is an important economic wealth if exploited, as well as 
achieving significant reductions in greenhouse gas emissions. The International Energy 
Agency (IEA) estimates that methane leaks (the main component of natural gas) in Iraq could 
be reduced by more than 80 per cent using existing technology. The financial value of Iraq's 
methane emissions is estimated at more than $600 million, which represents a significant 
economic loss. In addition to the economic benefits to Iraq of monetising this gas, reducing 
methane emissions protects human health by improving local air quality. 
 
The pathways adopted by the national sectors are described below: 
 
1-  Energy sector (oil, gas, electricity and transport): 
   Through this vital sector, Iraq seeks to voluntarily reduce its emissions if security and peace 
are available on the one hand and developed countries fulfil their commitments in terms of 
financing, transfer of environmentally friendly technology and capacity building on the other 
hand, as the highest percentage of greenhouse gas emissions comes from this sector, as stated 
in the First National Communication, which contributes 75% of Iraq's total emissions. 
Therefore, taking the following measures to reduce emissions from this sector will be 
beneficial from a developmental point of view: The following measures will be taken to 
reduce emissions from this sector: 
- 
Reduce levels of associated gas flaring and utilisation in upstream oil and natural 
gas operations. 
- 
Invest in and develop the petroleum industry to reduce both resource depletion and 
emissions. In particular, improve and monitor associated gas flaring technology to 
minimise methane emissions and avoid "venting" through good design, including 
through gas recovery and recycling. 
- 
Conduct LDAR programmes in collaboration with international partners (Global 
Methane Alliance (GMA-) and oil and gas companies operating in Iraq) to 
periodically detect methane leaks in oil and gas facilities for the purpose of 
remediation.  
15 
 
- 
 Utilising combined cycles to increase electricity production  
- 
Changing the type of liquid fuel to gaseous fuel in power plants and improving the 
quality of the fuel used to reduce carbon emissions. 
- 
Reduce emissions by improving energy efficiency and rationalising energy 
consumption. 
- 
Converting heavy fuel-fired power plants to LPG and dry gas, which can be saved 
by capturing associated gas and minimising methane emissions. 
- 
Utilise hydroelectricity, which is a clean source of energy. 
- 
The use of Carbon Capture and Storage (CCS) or Carbon Capture, Storage and 
Utilisation (CCUS) technologies to reduce carbon emissions and utilise it in 
industrial processes. 
- 
Localisation of renewable energy technology, especially  with regard to solar 
energy, due to Iraq's strategic location, which is considered a promising area for 
the localisation of this type of technology. 
- 
The use of advanced and sustainable public transport and environmentally friendly 
technologies such as the construction of the funicular project and the gradual shift 
towards sustainable transport. 
- 
A gradual shift towards hybrid and eco-friendly vehicles. 
- 
Aircraft with more fuel-efficient engines and more efficient operating systems. 
- 
Review and modernise existing laws and identify the need for new laws in relation 
to trade laws, industrial investment and customs tariffs. 
- 
Wind power production in promising areas, especially in the Kurdistan Region. 
- 
Support the participation of the private sector in the development of the public 
transport system in accordance with participatory mechanisms with the public 
sector. 
 
 
 
 
2- Industry sector: 
ُ The industrial sector, with its public, private and mixed aspects, is one of the components of 
the non-oil economy in Iraq, and the contribution of this sector to the gross domestic product 
(GDP) reached an average of 2.4% during the years (2008-2011). The Ministry of Industry 
and Minerals, which manages this sector, which is one of the sectors thatُ contribute to the 
emission of greenhouse gases through a set of measures: 
1. Developing and qualifying industrial processes in existing projects by introducing 
low-carbon technologies, such as cement, bricks, fertilisers and petrochemicals.  
2. Recycling and waste management, such as projects that recycle heat and gases from 
industrial furnaces and recycle plastics and tyres.  
3. Supporting the private industrial sector in the field of emission reduction by applying 
the mechanisms mentioned in the industrial strategy, such as small and medium-sized 
enterprises, to support the development of technological pathways, innovation and the 
transfer of environmentally friendly industrial technologies.  
3- Agriculture Sector  
16 
 
   The agricultural sector is an important economic sector in the country and is one of the 
main contributors to greenhouse gas emissions, as most of Iraq's crops are cereals such as 
wheat, barley, rice and maize, in addition to horticultural crops and palm trees. Therefore, the 
important measures in managing this sector to ensure a meaningful reduction in emissions 
can be summarised as follows: 
- 
Controlling the cultivation of crops that produce a large amount of methane gas, 
such as rice cultivation, as well as reducing its water consumption, combating soil 
erosion and rehabilitating degraded lands. 
- 
The use of alternative energy units such as solar and wind energy in the 
agricultural sector to operate irrigation pumps and the use of efficient irrigation 
systems. 
- 
Implement integrated management to combat natural forest fires and rehabilitate 
burned and degraded forests. Establish a system to protect and maintain natural and 
industrial forests, increase their areas and create green belts to minimise the 
emission of CO(2. 
- 
Increase environmental awareness on climate-smart agriculture. Improving 
nitrogen fertiliser application techniques to reduce N2O emissions and promoting 
no-till farming to reduce emissions from the use of agricultural machinery, as it has 
been successfully applied in the Kurdistan Region. 
- 
Reduce emissions from enteric fermentation in cattle and sheep by identifying and 
optimising suitable feeds. 
 
4- Waste sector: 
Iraq is seeking to localiseُ green investment in waste management to diversify its economy 
through the following measures: 
1- Passing the Solid Waste Management Law, which encourages waste recycling and 
waste-to-energy, and eliminates waste incineration. 
2- Using plasma technology to produce electricity from waste. 
3- Implementing an integrated waste management system. 
4- Utilising methane from landfill sites to produce electricity. 
5- Tire recycling project 
6- Energy production through waste treatment for electricity generation and heating, 
especially in modern cities adjacent to sewage treatment plants 
5- Housing sector: 
   Through the housing sector, Iraq seeks to apply the concepts of rationalising electricity 
consumption and moving towards low-emission pathways, depending  on the localisation of 
principles to stimulate the use of renewable energy in Iraq, as follows: 
1- Use energy-efficient lighting technologies. 
2- Using thermal insulation techniques. 
3- Issuing green building codes and modern technologies for thermal insulation, lighting 
and sustainable cities. 
4) Use efficient building design to maximise the use of lighting and solar energy. 
5- Implementation of photovoltaic technologies for distributed electricity in small towns 
and cities. 
17 
 
6- Integrated design that includes the use of smart meter technology within buildings. 
7- Integrated solar photovoltaic energy in buildings. 
8. Promote the production and use of environmentally friendly local building materials and 
products. 
9- Using modern construction techniques such as GRC and ICF, which are characterised by reducing the amount of 
rebar and cement used in construction 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Chapter Four 
Monitoring, reporting and verification: 
  ًًُ The monitoring, reporting and verification system is one of the most important 
requirements necessary to build a transparent system that reflects our needs according to a 
solid methodology through which we can draw clear paths to characterise the legislation, 
18 
 
laws and regulations necessary to reduce emissions and the implications of this on adaptation. 
This system will also help in assessing the country's national needs for technology and 
capacity building to enhance emission reduction pathways in measured quantities that can be 
reported with the availability of digital measurements based on a legislative platform that 
includes all sectors. 
   Through the support mechanisms of the UNFCCC and the Paris Agreement and in 
cooperation with the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP), Iraq seeks to obtain 
the necessary support to design the required monitoring format according to each sector, to 
include all forms of activities and all sectors in a flexible and scalable manner, as Iraq is 
aware that these systems willُ wellِ n the framework of transparency in the following: 
- 
National GHG inventory and reporting for each emitting activity. 
- 
Incentivise oil and gas companies operating in Iraq to report methane emissions 
within recognised transparent frameworks, such as the Oil, Gas and Methane 
Partnership (OGMP) framework.) 
- 
Collaborate on campaigns to directly measure methane emissions fromُ oil and gas 
facilities and use satellite data to establish a reference emissions baseline.  
- 
Evaluate the progress made in the implementation of the Nationally Determined 
Contribution (NDC). 
- 
Identify and assess the adverse effects of climate change on vulnerable sectors. 
- 
Characterising the co-benefits between mitigation and adaptation. 
- 
The impact of the implementation of response measures on the national economy. 
- 
Assessing national needs and the type of climate technology that contributes to the 
realisation of the Sustainable Development Goals 
- 
Identify the type of capacities that need to be built to ensure national mitigation 
actions are feasible in creating green jobs. 
- 
Determine the type of financing and investment that ensures the implementation of 
the national contribution in accordance with the country's national policy. 
- 
Localising technologies and software capable of creating predictive models for 
mitigation and adaptation  
- 
Characterising the verification profiles of actions taken to mitigate and adapt to 
climate change. 
- 
Identify the type, form and level of institutional structures required in accordance 
with international and national approaches to climate change. 
 
   Iraq is determined to advance the issue of climate change because it is aware of its 
seriousness at all levels as it seeks to establish the concepts of a green economy. However, 
the National Centre for Climate Change, which represents the institutional structure for 
managing climate change nationally, still needs more support to build and manage an 
integrated and transparent system for measurement, reporting and verification in particular, 
and to advance the status of the climate change file in general, as it needs international 
support financially, technically, technically and diplomatically ًًُIn order to build and manage 
an integrated and transparent system for measurement, reporting and verification in 
particular, and to improve the status of the climate change file in general, the National Centre 
for Climate Change needs international support financially  , technically  and diplomatically  to 
upgrade its climate capabilities and skills to enable it to participate in the formulation of 
international, regional and national policies to engage the international community in its 
actions to reduce the phenomenon of climate change. 
19 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Timeframe and implementation requirements: 
ُIraq aspires to implement its Nationally Determined Contributions for the time period from 
2021 to 2030 to achieve an expected reduction between 1%  - 2% of its total emissions 
according to the national greenhouse gas inventories by national effort and 15% when 
international financial and technical support is available and to achieve peace and security 
in accordance with the paths and directions outlined in this document in a way that ensures 
the achievement of mutual benefits to enable its vulnerable sectors to adapt to the harmful 
effects of climate change and after its people enjoy 24-hour electricity supply like the 
peoples of the world. The NAMA document will include details and implementation 
procedures, and will prioritise the electricity sector by investing in renewable energies 
worth up to 12 GW, based on the economic decisions of the Council of Ministers for 2021. 
 
Iraq can achieve reductions in its emissions and adaptation of its sectors after fulfilling the 
following requirements: 
▪ International financial support of up to $100 billion in accordance with the timeframe 
outlined in this document through grants and localisation of sustainable investment in 
the public and private sectors. 
▪ Supporting innovation and transfer of environmentally friendly technologies in line 
with national needs. 
▪ Stabilising the oil market in particular and ensuring that the national economy does 
not fluctuate in order to achieve the realisation of development plans in light of the 
sustainable development goals and in a way that contributes to diversifying the 
f it

Title: EU NDC 2023 update
text_content:
1 
 
Update of the 
NDC of the European Union and its Member States 
SUBMISSION BY SPAIN AND THE EUROPEAN COMMISSION ON BEHALF OF THE 
EUROPEAN UNION AND ITS MEMBER STATES 
Madrid, 16 October 2023 
Subject: 
The update of the nationally determined contribution of the European Union and 
its Member States 
 
This submission consists of three parts: 1) overview, 2) the EU’s updated Nationally Determined 
Contribution (NDC) and 3) the Information provided to facilitate Clarity, Transparency and 
Understanding (ICTU) of the NDC. 
 
I. 
OVERVIEW  
Summary of procedural developments 
1. 
The European Union and its Member States submitted their intended nationally 
determined contribution (INDC) on 6 March 2015, together with an annex 
containing quantifiable and qualitative information on the INDC, in line with 
decisions taken at the 20th session of the Conference of the Parties (COP) in Lima. 
2. 
The EU’s INDC became its NDC when the EU ratified the Paris Agreement in 
October 2016, with a target of at least 40% economy-wide reduction of 
greenhouse gas emissions by 2030, compared to 1990 levels.  
3. 
In December 2019, the European Council (heads of state or government of the EU 
Member States, the European Council President, and the President of the European 
Commission) endorsed the objective of achieving a climate-neutral EU by 2050, in 
line with the Paris Agreement. On 5 March 2020, the Council of the European 
Union adopted a long-term low greenhouse gas emission development strategy of the 
EU and its Member States, reflecting this climate neutrality objective and 
submitted it to the UNFCCC Secretariat. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
2 
 
Update of the 
NDC of the European Union and its Member States 
4. 
On the 11 December 2020 the European Council endorsed a new and more 
ambitious EU climate target for 2030 applicable to the EU and its 27 Member 
States of “a net domestic reduction of at least 55% in greenhouse gas 
emissions by 2030 compared to 1990” and submitted it to the UNFCCC 
Secretariat as an updated and enhanced NDC on 18 December 20201.  
5. 
On 30 June 2021, the EU published a Regulation setting out a binding objective of 
climate neutrality in the European Union by 2050 at the latest, aiming to achieve 
negative emissions thereafter, and establishing the legal framework for achieving 
climate neutrality, known as the European Climate Law2. The European Climate 
Law confirmed the domestic reduction of net greenhouse gas emissions by at least 
55% by 2030 compared to 1990, setting it as a legally binding target. 
6. 
On 14 July 2021, the European Commission adopted the “Fit for 55” set of 
proposals to revise and update EU legislation with the aim of ensuring that EU 
policies are in line with the climate goals set in the European Climate Law.  
 
 
 
1 
https://unfccc.int/sites/default/files/NDC/2022-
06/EU_NDC_Submission_December%202020.pdf  
2 
Regulation (EU) 2021/1119 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 30 June 2021 
establishing the framework for achieving climate neutrality and amending Regulations (EC) 
No 401/2009 and (EU) 2018/1999 (‘European Climate Law’) 
 
 
 
 
3 
 
Update of the 
NDC of the European Union and its Member States 
7. 
In 2023 the Council of the European Union and the European Parliament formally 
adopted all the essential elements of the legislative framework necessary to 
implement the “Fit for 55”, and the agreed legislation3 has been published in the 
official Journal of the European Union.  
8. 
Details on policies relevant to the implementation of the NDC have been reviewed 
in light of the adoption of the “Fit for 55” legislative framework and the 
respective updates are presented in this Part and Part 3 of this submission (the 
ICTU). 
9. 
According to the Commission´s estimates, the “Fit for 55” legislative framework, when 
fully implemented, could enable the EU and its MS to overachieve the EU´s net 
domestic reduction of greenhouse gas emissions target of at least 55% compared to 
1990 by 2030. 
10. 
With this submission, the EU updates information on its NDC in advance of COP28 
and requests the UNFCCC Secretariat to consider relevant technical information 
contained in this submission in the Secretariat’s NDC Synthesis Report.

Regulation (EU) 2023/839 of the European Parliament and of the Council amending

4 
 
Update of the 
NDC of the European Union and its Member States 
The main domestic policies adopted in view of the new climate target agreed in 
December 2020 are summarized in the following paragraphs as well as in Part 3 of this 
document (ICTU). 
11. 
Emissions reduction targets under the EU legislation are covered by the EU 
Emissions Trading System (EU ETS), the Effort Sharing Regulation (ESR), and 
the regulation on land-use related emissions and removals (LULUCF). Additional 
legislation and policies on CO2 emission performance standards for new passenger 
cars and for new light commercial vehicles, renewable energy and energy 
efficiency, part of the “Fit for 55%” framework also contribute towards the 
achievement of the EU’s climate targets for 2030.  
12. 
The EU ETS, which has been operational since 2005, puts a price on carbon by 
setting a cap on the maximum number of emission allowances for its covered 
sectors. The EU has reviewed and amended its legislation setting a new target to 
reduce emissions from the existing EU ETS sectors and from maritime of 62% 
by 2030, compared to 2005 levels. 
13. 
The extension of the EU ETS to maritime emissions will cover CO2, methane and 
nitrous oxide emissions from ships above 5000 gross tonnage and will apply to 50% 
of emissions from voyages starting or ending outside the EU, and all emissions 
from voyages within the EU and emissions from ships within EU ports.  
14. 
With regard to commercial aviation, the EU ETS will continue to apply effective 
carbon pricing for intra-European flights and departing flights to the United 
Kingdom and to Switzerland. In addition, legislation is in place to apply the Carbon 
Offsetting and Reduction Scheme for International Aviation of the International 
Civil Aviation Organization (CORSIA), as appropriate, to EU-based aircraft 
operators for flights to and from other third countries participating in CORSIA, and 
to apply carbon pricing to emissions from flights involving third countries which do 
not apply CORSIA from the start of 2027. 
 
 
 
 
5 
 
Update of the 
NDC of the European Union and its Member States 
15. 
The revision of the EU ETS Directive also applies a separate carbon pricing 
framework to fuel combustion in road transport and buildings and additional 
sectors (ETS2) and is designed to price emissions from 20274 without free 
allocation and to contribute to 42% emission reductions by 2030 compared to 
2005 in the sectors covered. 
16. 
Under the revised Effort Sharing Regulation, the EU legislation sets enhanced 
individual binding reduction targets for Member States for greenhouse gas emissions 
not covered by the existing EU ETS, namely domestic transport (except aviation), 
buildings, agriculture, waste and small industries with an EU-level greenhouse gas 
emissions reduction target of 40% by 2030 compared to 2005.  
17. 
In the LULUCF sector, the EU adopted a Union net greenhouse gas removals 
target of 310 million tonnes of CO2 equivalent, as a sum of the reported 
greenhouse gas net emissions and removals in the sector in 2030. Moreover, the new 
legislation now includes all emissions and removals reported for all managed land in 
the Union.  
18. 
With regard to new cars and vans, the EU adopted legislation to reduce 55% of 
CO2 emissions for new cars and 50% for new vans from 2030 until 2034, and 
for 100% CO2 emissions reductions from 2035 for new cars and vans. 
19. 
Ambitious targets for improving energy efficiency and for increasing 
renewables in the EU energy mix have been agreed. In line with the European 
Commission’s plan to make Europe independent from Russian fossil fuels well 
before 2030, (RePowerEU), the EU has agreed to increase ambition on energy 
savings through an enhanced target to reduce final energy consumption at EU 
level by 11.7% in 2030 and a new target for increasing renewable energy in final 
energy consumption of at least 42.5% by 2030, with an additional 2.5% indicative 
top up that would allow to reach 45%. 
 
4 
In case of exceptionally high prices of gas and oil in the months prior to the foreseen 
beginning of the ETS2, this system will begin operating from 2028. However, the ambition in 
terms of GHG reductions remains unchanged. 
 
 
 
 
6 
 
Update of the 
NDC of the European Union and its Member States 
Additional elements related to the EU’s overall efforts on climate action 
20. 
Sustainable transport fuels can play a key role in reducing greenhouse gas 
emissions. In March and April 2023 respectively, the Council of the European Union 
and the European Parliament reached an agreement on the FuelEU maritime and 
the RefuelEU aviation proposals to increase the uptake of sustainable fuels by 
aircraft and ships and reduce their environmental footprint. 
21. 
A regulation on the deployment of alternative fuels infrastructure to ensure that 
the public has access to a sufficient infrastructure network for recharging or 
refuelling road vehicles or ships with alternative fuels has been adopted by the 
European Parliament and the Council of the European Union and it will soon enter 
into force. The proposed regulation will play an important role in speeding up the 
deployment of this infrastructure so that the adoption of zero- and low-emission 
vehicles and ships will not be impeded, initiating a virtuous circle, and enabling the 
transport sector to significantly reduce its carbon footprint. 
22. 
In the context of the European Green Deal, EU leaders endorsed in July 2020 that an 
overall climate target of 30% would apply to the total amount of expenditure 
from the EU Budget and additional recovery instruments with a view to comply 
with the objective of EU climate neutrality by 2050 and contribute to achieving the 
Union's new 2030 climate target. They confirmed that as a general principle, all EU 
expenditure should be consistent with Paris Agreement objectives. With this and 
other measures such as the EU ETS, and additional financial market policies, e.g. the 
EU Sustainable Finance Framework, the EU supports the implementation of 
Article 2.1.(c) to make finance flows consistent with a low greenhouse gas emission 
and climate resilient development pathway. 
 
 
 
 
7 
 
Update of the 
NDC of the European Union and its Member States 
23. 
In order to contribute to the transition towards a climate-neutral economy in a fair 
way, leaving no one behind the EU established a Social Climate Fund to support 
vulnerable households, micro-enterprises and transport users in coping with the 
price impacts of the new emissions trading system for the buildings and road 
transport and fuels for additional sectors. In principle a maximum amount of 
EUR 65 billion should be made available for the period 2026-2032 in line with the 
articles set out in its Regulation5. 
24. 
The EU ETS revision also strengthens the EU ETS-funded Modernisation Fund to 
contribute to the significant investment needs of the 13 lower-income Member 
States, as of 2024. It includes support for investments to modernise the energy 
systems and improve energy efficiency in energy storage, generation and use of 
renewable sources and modernisation of energy networks, including pipelines, grids 
and district heating, promoting a just transition in carbon dependent regions. The 
Modernisation Fund is funded from revenues from the auctioning of 2% of the total 
allowances for 2021-30 under the EU ETS and additional allowances transferred by 
beneficiary Member States – 5 opted to do so. An additional 2.5% of the total 
quantity of allowances between 2024 and 2030 will also be auctioned for the 
Modernisation fund.  
25. 
In addition, the EU ETS’s Innovation Fund is one of the world’s largest funding 
programmes for the demonstration of innovative low-carbon technologies. The 
Innovation Fund, funded 100% by the EU ETS, will provide around EUR 38 billion 
of support from 2020 to 2030 (calculated at EUR 75 / tCO2), depending on the 
carbon price, for the commercial demonstration of innovative low-carbon 
technologies, aiming to bring to the market industrial solutions to decarbonise 
Europe and support its transition to climate neutrality. 
 
5 
REGULATION (EU) 2023/955 OF THE EUROPEAN PARLIAMENT AND OF THE COUNCIL of 
10 May 2023 establishing a Social Climate Fund and amending Regulation (EU) 2021/1060 
 
 
 
 
8 
 
Update of the 
NDC of the European Union and its Member States 
26. 
A carbon border adjustment mechanism (CBAM) will put a price on the carbon 
content of imports of a targeted selection of products. The primary objective of 
CBAM is to prevent carbon leakage and increases in emissions in third countries by 
ensuring certain imported products bear the same carbon price as EU domestic 
producers. It will be applied in a non-discriminatory manner consistent with 
international trade rules, and its application will provide the basis for deeper 
international cooperation.  
27. 
The EU is committed to promoting a human rights-based and gender-responsive 
approach to climate action, promoting social justice, fairness and inclusiveness in 
the global transition towards climate neutrality, full, equal and meaningful 
participation and engagement of women in climate-related decision-making and 
fully meeting our human rights obligations when taking action to address climate 
change.

The EU’s at least 55% net reduction target by 2030 is to be achieved 
through domestic measures only, without contribution from international 
credits. 
 
Norway, Iceland and Liechtenstein have been participating in the EU ETS 
since 2008, and an agreement linking the EU and Swiss emissions trading 
systems entered into force in 2020. The EU is continuing to explore the 
possibilities to link the EU ETS with other robust emissions trading 
systems. 
 
The EU will account for its cooperation through the EU ETS with these 
and any other Parties in a manner consistent with the guidance adopted by 
CMA1 and any further guidance agreed by the CMA. 
6 
How the Party considers that its nationally determined contribution is fair and ambitious in the light of its national circumstances: 
(a) 
How the Party considers that its nationally determined 
contribution is fair and ambitious in the light of its 
national circumstances; 
The EU’s NDC is both ambitious and fair as it will set one of the world’s 
largest fossil fuel-dependent and industrialized economies, on a pathway to 
climate neutrality by 2050, while taking into account fairness and solidarity 
across Member States with diverse national circumstances.  
 
The NDC reflects the EU’s 2030 target, made binding by the European 
Climate Law that also commits the EU to be climate neutral by 2050. The 
2030 target will be delivered collectively by the EU, in the most cost-
effective manner possible, through the “Fit for 55” package of legislation. 
All EU Member States will participate in this effort in a way that takes 
account of Member States’ different starting points and specific national 
circumstances and emission reduction potential, including those of island 
Member States and islands, as well as their efforts made to date. 
 
The European Climate Law creates a system for monitoring progress and 
provides a legal basis for taking further action if needed. It provides 
predictability for investors and other economic actors and ensures that the 
transition to climate neutrality is irreversible.  
 
 
21 
 
 
The EU has a long track record of delivering on its climate policies. Its total 
GHG emissions (excluding LULUCF and international aviation) decreased 
by 1939 million tonnes CO2 eq. since 1990 (or 34,3%) reaching its lowest 
level during this period in 2020 (3708 million tonnes CO2 eq.). The EU has 
progressively decoupled its gross domestic product (GDP) from its GHG 
emissions compared to 1990, with an increase in GDP by 54% alongside a 
decrease in emissions of about 34% over the same period. 
 
In order to ensure that the transition towards a climate-neutral economy 
happens in a fair way, leaving no one behind the EU established a Social 
Climate Fund to support vulnerable households, micro-enterprises and 
transport users in coping with the price impacts of the new emissions 
trading system for the buildings and road transport and fuels for additional 
sectors. The Fund should be exceptionally and temporarily directly financed 
by the revenue of allowances from the ETS. 
 
The EU ETS revision also strengthens the EU ETS-funded Modernisation 
Fund to contribute to the significant investment needs of the 13 lower-
income Member States, as of 2024. It includes support for investments in 
energy storage, generation and use of renewable sources and modernisation 
of energy networks, including pipelines, grids and district heating, 
promoting a just transition in carbon dependent regions.  
(b) 
Fairness considerations, including reflecting on equity; 
According to the IPCC 6th Assessment Report, global greenhouse gas 
emissions need to fall by about 43% below 2019 levels by 2030 to be on 
track for limiting warming to 1.5°C. The EU’s “at least -55%” target is 
consistent with this level of reduction, building on the substantial emissions 
reductions achieved by the EU since the base year 1990. 
 
The most ambitious IPCC scenarios (consistent with 1.5°C with no or 
limited overshoot) are similar to those of the 2018 Special Report on 1.5°C 
which informed the EU’s “at least -55%“ target, as well as the EU’s 2050 
 
22 
 
 
climate neutrality objective. Achieving these objectives will mean that EU 
decarbonizes faster than the pace needed for the world as whole in these 
scenarios. For 2050, the EU objective of achieving climate neutrality goes 
beyond the net zero level for CO2 (only) needed at global level around that 
time.  
 
It should also be noted that the EU has already reduced greenhouse 
emissions to 31% below 1990 levels, while emissions have risen by over 
50% worldwide. The EU has substantially exceeded its 2020 targets, even 
without taking the effects of the COVID-19 pandemic into account. During 
that period, the EU and its Member States’ emissions reductions outpaced 
those of any other major developed or developing economy. 
 
On a per capita basis, EU emissions are also among the lowest of any major 
high-income economy and lower than several emerging economies. 
 
The IPCC 6th Assessment Report also confirms that a sustained commitment 
to climate action, like the EU’s, has been effective in the regions where it 
has been attempted. It also finds that sustained climate policies have led to 
cost reductions for low emission technologies and multi-year emissions 
reductions (even when measured on a consumption basis), and it found no 
evidence of significant emissions leakage from well-managed carbon pricing 
policies. 
(c) 
How the Party has addressed Article 4, paragraph 3, of the Paris 
Agreement; 
This NDC represents a progression of ambition compared to its initial NDC 
for the same timeframe. See 6a 
(d) 
How the Party has addressed Article 4, paragraph 4, of the Paris 
Agreement 
The EU complies with this provision by having an economy-wide absolute 
target 
(e)

Agreement. 
Not applicable to the EU 
 
23 
 
 
 
7

(b)
